clusters.title: Israel strikes Doha in attack it says targeted Hamas officials
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Strikes Qatar, Targeting Hamas Officials
bullet_summary: President Trump said Tuesday he's "very unhappy" after Israel's military targeted members of Hamas in Qatar's capital of Doha
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he approved the strikes after Hamas claimed responsibility for a terror attack on a bus stop in Jerusalem that killed six Israelis
Six people were killed in Israeli attack on Doha, but Hamas senior leaders are reported to have survived
US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday

items.title: Israel strikes Doha in attack it says targeted Hamas officials
items.standfirst: Israel on Tuesday launched an airstrike in Qatar that hit a building used for ceasefire negotiations between Hamas and Israel. Although Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the attack targeted senior Hamas officials, the UN and leaders around the world, including the US, condemned the attack as a violation of Qatar's national sovereignty.
items.content: Israel on Tuesday launched an airstrike in Qatar that hit a building used for ceasefire negotiations between Hamas and Israel. Although Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the attack targeted senior Hamas officials, the UN and leaders around the world, including the US, condemned the attack as a violation of Qatar's national sovereignty.

The target was a meeting of senior Hamas officials in the capital, Doha. Nick…

items.title: 'Cracks are showing' in the US-Israel relationship as Israel strikes Doha
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday. While eliminating Hamas was a "worthy goal," a strike in the Qatari capital Doha "does not advance Israel or America's goals," White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters, reading from a statement. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: US President Donald Trump did not agree with Israel's choice to conduct strikes against Hamas inside US ally Qatar, the White House said Tuesday. While eliminating Hamas was a "worthy goal," a strike in the Qatari capital Doha "does not advance Israel or America's goals," White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters, reading from a statement. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Hamas says six dead in Israeli strike including Qatari security officer
items.standfirst: Hamas said six people were killed in an Israeli strike on the group's compound in Doha on Tuesday, including its top negotiator's son and a Qatari security officer. Three bodyguards and Gaza ceasefire negotiator Khalil al-Hayya's aide and son were all killed in the attack, the group said, affirming "the enemy's failure to assassinate our brothers in the negotiating delegation". FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot reports.
items.content: Hamas said six people were killed in an Israeli strike on the group's compound in Doha on Tuesday, including its top negotiator's son and a Qatari security officer. Three bodyguards and Gaza ceasefire negotiator Khalil al-Hayya's aide and son were all killed in the attack, the group said, affirming "the enemy's failure to assassinate our brothers in the negotiating delegation". FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot reports.

clusters.title: Macron appoints Defense Minister Sebastien Lecornu as new Prime Minister
clusters.neutral_headline: French President Names New Prime Minister
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, Reuters Top News, Al Jazeera and others

items.title: Macron appoints Defense Minister Sebastien Lecornu as new Prime Minister
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday appointed Defense Minister Sebastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minister after François Bayrou tendered his resignation over a vote of no confidence. Lecornu, Macron's third prime minister in the past year, faces the daunting task of passing the national budget through a gridlocked National Assembly.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday appointed Defense Minister Sebastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minister after François Bayrou tendered his resignation over a vote of no confidence. Lecornu, Macron's third prime minister in the past year, faces the daunting task of passing the national budget through a gridlocked National Assembly.

items.title: How the boomers crippled France
items.standfirst: To no one’s surprise, François Bayrou and his government have been deposed by France’s National Assembly following a confidence vote that Bayrou triggered himself. Given the parliamentary arithmetic, Bayrou’s defenestration was far from remarkable. What was remarkable, however, was an unexpected…
items.content: To no one’s surprise, François Bayrou and his government have been deposed by France’s National Assembly following a confidence vote that Bayrou triggered himself. Given the parliamentary arithmetic, Bayrou’s defenestration was far from remarkable. What was remarkable, however, was an unexpected…

items.title: Macron names close ally Lecornu new PM
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday named armed forces minister and his close ally Sebastien Lecornu as the new prime minister to replace Francois Bayrou as the seventh premier of his mandate. The formal handover of power between Bayrou and Lecornu is due to take place on Wednesday at midday. FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin reports.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday named armed forces minister and his close ally Sebastien Lecornu as the new prime minister to replace Francois Bayrou as the seventh premier of his mandate. The formal handover of power between Bayrou and Lecornu is due to take place on Wednesday at midday. FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin reports.

items.title: Macron names close ally Sebastien Lecornu as new French PM
items.standfirst: Sebastien Lecornu, 39, is facing an uphill battle over budget as protests loom in the coming days.
items.content: Sebastien Lecornu, 39, is facing an uphill battle over budget as protests loom in the coming days.

items.title: France's new PM tasked with forging consensus on a 2026 budget
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has picked defence chief Sébastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minsiter a day after François Bayrou was voted out in parliament. The 39-year-old's immediate priority will be to try and forge consensus on a new budget, before forming a government. If this year's budget were to be carried over into next year, France's fiscal deficit, already the highest in the EU, is predicted to widen further.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has picked defence chief Sébastien Lecornu as his new Prime Minsiter a day after François Bayrou was voted out in parliament. The 39-year-old's immediate priority will be to try and forge consensus on a new budget, before forming a government. If this year's budget were to be carried over into next year, France's fiscal deficit, already the highest in the EU, is predicted to widen further.

items.title: Macron names ally Sébastien Lecornu as new French PM
items.standfirst: It comes after a vote of confidence ousted François Bayrou after nine months in power.
items.content: It comes after a vote of confidence ousted François Bayrou after nine months in power.

items.title: Emmanuel Macron appoints his third prime minister in a year
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu, a presidential ally, is tasked with bringing France’s divided parties together to pass a budgetSébastien Lecornu, a close ally of Emmanuel Macron, has been appointed prime minister, tasked with consulting France’s divided political parties to try to find a consensus on the budget.The 39-year-old began his political career in the traditional rightwing party of Nicolas Sarkozy before moving to Macron’s centre in 2017 and is seen as fiercely loyal to the president. Continue reading...
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu, a presidential ally, is tasked with bringing France’s divided parties together to pass a budgetSébastien Lecornu, a close ally of Emmanuel Macron, has been appointed prime minister, tasked with consulting France’s divided political parties to try to find a consensus on the budget.The 39-year-old began his political career in the traditional rightwing party of Nicolas Sarkozy before moving to Macron’s centre in 2017 and is seen as fiercely loyal to the president. Continue reading...

items.title: It will be surprising that Lecornu survives as French PM more than a year, analyst says
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday named Minister of the Armed Forces Sébastien Lecornu as the new prime minister to replace Francois Bayrou, who survived just nine months in office, the presidency said. Thibault Muzergues, Political Director at Shared Ground think tank, says that it will be surprising that the new Prime Minister will survive more than a year
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday named Minister of the Armed Forces Sébastien Lecornu as the new prime minister to replace Francois Bayrou, who survived just nine months in office, the presidency said. Thibault Muzergues, Political Director at Shared Ground think tank, says that it will be surprising that the new Prime Minister will survive more than a year

items.title: French President Emmanuel Macron appoints Defence Minister Sébastien Lecornu as new PM
After Bayrou: What happens now that France has ousted yet another prime minister?
items.standfirst: Another one bites the dust. Prime Minister François Bayrou on Tuesday became the fourth premier in less than two years to submit his resignation after losing a crushing confidence vote in parliament. As President Emmanuel Macron scrambles to find a successor, can France find a way out of its deepening political crisis?
items.content: Another one bites the dust. Prime Minister François Bayrou on Tuesday became the fourth premier in less than two years to submit his resignation after losing a crushing confidence vote in parliament. As President Emmanuel Macron scrambles to find a successor, can France find a way out of its deepening political crisis?

items.title: France's ruling government collapses in major blow to President Emmanuel Macron
items.standfirst: France's National Assembly is set to vote for a motion of no confidence in François Bayrou, less than a year after they did the same for Michel Barnier.
items.content: France's National Assembly is set to vote for a motion of no confidence in François Bayrou, less than a year after they did the same for Michel Barnier.

ai_summary: Macron appointed Sebastien Lecornu as the new French Prime Minister.
Lecornu replaces Francois Bayrou, who resigned after a no-confidence vote.
Lecornu is Macron's third prime minister in the past year.
Lecornu faces the task of passing the national budget.
The formal handover of power is scheduled for Wednesday at midday.

Bush administration and former director of the Congressional Budget Office, joins with analysis.

items.standfirst: Revision highlights recent concerns about the health of the labor market, and follows a lackluster August jobs reportBusiness live – latest updatesThe US added 911,000 fewer jobs than first estimated for the year to March 2025, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) announced on Tuesday, highlighting recent concerns about the health of the labor market.The revisions are 50% higher than last year’s adjustment and were on the higher end of Wall Street estimates between 600,000 and 1 million. items.title: Ethiopia launches Africa's largest hydroelectric dam, sparking Egyptian protest
items.standfirst: Standing 170 metres high and stretching nearly 2 km across the Blue Nile, Ethiopia has officially unveiled the largest hydroelectric dam in Africa. While it is expected to supply electricity to millions of Ethiopians, it also risks exacerbating tensions with neighbouring Egypt and Sudan, who are concerned about their water reserves.
items.content: Standing 170 metres high and stretching nearly 2 km across the Blue Nile, Ethiopia has officially unveiled the largest hydroelectric dam in Africa. While it is expected to supply electricity to millions of Ethiopians, it also risks exacerbating tensions with neighbouring Egypt and Sudan, who are concerned about their water reserves.

items.standfirst: Ethiopia opens Africa's largest hydropower project, the Blue Nile's Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam — a milestone that's sparking alarm in neighboring Sudan and Egypt.
items.content: Ethiopia opens Africa's largest hydropower project, the Blue Nile's Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam — a milestone that's sparking alarm in neighboring Sudan and Egypt.(Image credit: Brian Inganga)

items.standfirst: Ethiopian PM says dam will electrify entire region but Egypt fears it could restrict water supply during droughtsEthiopia has inaugurated Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam, a project that could transform the country’s energy sector but may also aggravate tensions with neighbouring Egypt.State media showed the Ethiopian prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, touring the site of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) in Guba district with the Kenyan president, William Ruto, the Somali president, Hassan Sheikh Mohamud, and the African Union chairperson, Mahmoud Ali Youssouf. Continue reading...
items.content: Ethiopian PM says dam will electrify entire region but Egypt fears it could restrict water supply during droughtsEthiopia has inaugurated Africa’s largest hydroelectric dam, a project that could transform the country’s energy sector but may also aggravate tensions with neighbouring Egypt.State media showed the Ethiopian prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, touring the site of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) in Guba district with the Kenyan president, William Ruto, the Somali president, Hassan Sheikh Mohamud, and the African Union chairperson, Mahmoud Ali Youssouf. Continue reading...

items.title: Nepal prime minister quits after deaths at protests sparked by social media ban
items.standfirst: KP Sharma Oli resigns as police meet protests with deadly force, leaving 19 dead, and federal parliament is set alight Nepal’s prime minister has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontent at political corruption and nepotism.KP Sharma Oli’s resignation came a day after widespread protests were met with deadly force by police, leaving 19 dead and hundreds injured. The spark for the protests was a government ban on 26 prominent social media apps, but escalated into a larger mass movement against corruption among political elites. Continue reading...
items.content: KP Sharma Oli resigns as police meet protests with deadly force, leaving 19 dead, and federal parliament is set alight Nepal’s prime minister has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontent at political corruption and nepotism.KP Sharma Oli’s resignation came a day after widespread protests were met with deadly force by police, leaving 19 dead and hundreds injured. The spark for the protests was a government ban on 26 prominent social media apps, but escalated into a larger mass movement against corruption among political elites. Continue reading...

items.title: At least 19 killed in ‘gen Z’ protests against Nepal’s social media ban
items.standfirst: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...
items.content: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. items.title: Iran resumes cooperation with UN nuclear watchdog under new framework

clusters.title: Pigs' heads left outside mosques in Paris region
clusters.neutral_headline: Pigs' Heads Found Outside Mosques in Paris
bullet_summary: At least nine pigs' heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city's police chief said -- an incident that has sparked alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred
Reported by France24, Guardian World

items.title: Pigs' heads left outside mosques in Paris region
items.standfirst: At least nine pigs' heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city's police chief said -- an incident that has sparked alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred. FRANCE 24's Daniel Quinlan reports.
items.content: At least nine pigs' heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city's police chief said -- an incident that has sparked alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred. FRANCE 24's Daniel Quinlan reports.

items.title: At least nine pigs’ heads found outside mosques in Paris region
items.standfirst: Police do not rule out possibility of finding more as incidents raise alarm over increase of anti-Muslim hatred At least nine pigs’ heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city’s police chief said, prompting alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred.“Pigs’ heads have been left in front of certain mosques ... Four in Paris and five in the inner suburbs,” Laurent Nuñez told a press conference, adding that officers were not “ruling out the possibility of finding more”. Continue reading...
items.content: Police do not rule out possibility of finding more as incidents raise alarm over increase of anti-Muslim hatred At least nine pigs’ heads were found outside several mosques in the Paris region on Tuesday, the city’s police chief said, prompting alarm over rising anti-Muslim hatred.“Pigs’ heads have been left in front of certain mosques ... Four in Paris and five in the inner suburbs,” Laurent Nuñez told a press conference, adding that officers were not “ruling out the possibility of finding more”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Pigs' heads were found outside several mosques in Paris.
The incidents have sparked alarm over anti-Muslim hatred.
Police are not ruling out finding more incidents.
The incidents occurred in Paris and its suburbs.
The incidents occurred in Paris and its suburbs.
